title: Survey
text: Survey

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Project Overview
Goal
Build an interactive personal data portfolio website that will:
- Showcase my technical skills in data analysis, visualization, and web development.
- Host interactive dashboards, surveys, and multiple data analysis projects.
- Serve as an interactive CV to highlight my experience and achievements.

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Key Features

Interactive Dashboards:
Dynamic, engaging visualizations created with tools like R and Shiny.
Survey Integration:
Embedded surveys to gather user insights and display synthetic data analysis.
Data Portfolio:
A collection of projects and visualizations that demonstrate advanced data techniques.
Personal Branding:
An interactive CV that effectively communicates professional milestones and skills.

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Technology & Tools

Quarto:
For building, publishing, and presenting the interactive website.
R & ggplot2:
For data visualization and analysis.
Shiny:
To add interactivity and dynamic components.
Other Tools:
Python, Observable, and GitHub for version control and additional functionalities.

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Project Timeline

Design & Planning:
Jan 1 – Jan 15, 2025
Data Preparation:
Jan 16 – Jan 31, 2025
Development:
Feb 1 – Feb 15, 2025
Testing & Refinement:
Feb 16 – Feb 25, 2025
Launch & Presentation:
Feb 26 – Mar 01, 2025

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Grading Criteria Addressed

Project Scope:
Advanced, multifaceted project integrating interactive dashboards and surveys.
Technical Interpretation:
Demonstrates proficient use of R, ggplot2, and additional tools to create compelling visualizations.
Professional Presentation:
A clean, polished online presentation using Quarto and reveal.js that effectively communicates the project plan.

title: Final Project: Personal Data Portfolio
text:
Final Notes
This project represents a comprehensive personal data portfolio that not only showcases my technical capabilities but also serves as an interactive resume. It reflects careful planning, innovative design, and practical application of data visualization and interactivity. I look forward to presenting this project and receiving feedback.

title: Visualizations
text: Visualizations

title: Digital Habits & Screen Time Survey Report
text:
This report summarizes the synthetic data generated from our “Digital Habits & Screen Time Survey”. It includes summary statistics and visualizations that reflect digital habits across different demographics.



Screen Time Scale:
1 = Less than 2 hours, 5 = More than 8 hours
Phone Anxiety Scale:
1 = Strongly disagree, 5 = Strongly agree



Summary Statistics by Age Group


Age_Group
Avg. Screen Time (1-5)
Avg. Phone Anxiety (1-5)




Under 18
4.21
4.41


18-24
3.87
4.62


25-34
2.82
3.32


35-44
2.81
3.45


45-54
1.88
2.29


55-64
1.73
2.27


65+
2.00
1.67









Younger age groups spend significantly more time on screens and experience higher phone-related anxiety.

The Under 18 group reports the highest screen time (4.21) and phone anxiety (4.41), suggesting a strong dependency on digital devices. The 18-24 group follows closely, with slightly less screen time (3.87) but the highest phone anxiety (4.62), indicating heightened stress or attachment to their phones.

Screen time and phone anxiety gradually decrease with age.

The 25-34 and 35-44 age groups show a notable drop in screen time (2.82 and 2.81, respectively) and phone anxiety (3.32 and 3.45). This suggests a more balanced relationship with technology compared to younger users.

Older adults (45+) use screens the least and report the lowest phone anxiety.

The 45-54 and 55-64 groups show further declines in screen time (1.88 and 1.73) and anxiety (2.29 and 2.27). The 65+ group has the lowest values for both (2.00 screen time, 1.67 phone anxiety), indicating that they may use phones more functionally rather than habitually or emotionally.



The data highlights a strong correlation between age, screen time, and phone anxiety. Younger individuals—especially those under 25—spend the most time on screens and report the highest levels of anxiety related to phone use. As people age, both metrics steadily decline, suggesting that older users may have a more controlled or less emotionally attached relationship with their devices.

title: Course overview
text:
What is a Dashboard?

Dashboards provide a visual display of the most important information needed to achieve one or more objectives.
They consolidate and arrange information on a single screen.

Key Characteristics of Effective Dashboards

Clarity: Information should be easy to read and interpret.
Accuracy: Data must be accurate and up-to-date.
Relevance: Content should align with user goals and needs.

title: Course overview
text: Definition by Stephen Few

title: Course overview
text:
The Role of Visual Design

Minimize distractions and unnecessary elements.
Use consistent layouts and formatting.
Apply thoughtful use of color and typography.

Best Practices for Dashboard Design

Avoid clutter: Only display essential information.
Prioritize data: Highlight key metrics and KPIs.
Use visual hierarchy: Direct the viewer’s focus to the most important elements.

title: Course overview
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Overloading the user with too much data.
Using overly complex or inconsistent designs.
Neglecting the importance of user testing.

What You Shoud Do

Focus on the needs and goals of the dashboard’s end-users.
Iteratively test and refine designs to improve usability.

title: Course overview
text:
Summary

Dashboards are powerful tools for decision-making.
Effective dashboards balance clarity, relevance, and visual appeal.
Avoid common pitfalls by focusing on user needs and testing designs.
